Could you not measure dark energy and possibly harness it by putting a long cord with two large weights on either end and a generator with monitoring equipment in the middle? Dark energy would pull the space in between the weight apart, creating a force. The weights would carry the force, and the generator would harness the pulling force. The monitoring equipment would detect ripples and the strength of forces inside/on the cord, providing data that could be used to discern the nature of dark energy. This is certainly not very easy to do and requires a lot of resources, but it could be done.

Great video, but PLEASE don't use "just a theory" as a synonym for hypothesis. A theory is a set of facts that explains a phenomenon. Laws are parts of theories. Gravity is a theory. Germs are a theory. Evolution is a theory. Electromagnetism is a theory. When you say that something is "just a theory", it diminishes the word.

It's like calling a new shirt "awesome". While it may be nice, it cannot hold a wet match to the vastness and complexity of the universe.

How do we know that there is no dark matter, but instead some other form of invisible matter that repels normal matter instead of attracting it? For this idea to work, our measurements of gravity would have to be too small.

This form of matter would be spread throughout the universe and would be of a high enough concentration in our solar system that it would counteract some of the effects of gravity. Thus, our ideas of gravity's pull would be too small.

Extrapolating on this, other galaxies that we observe as moving "too fast" would simply be moving under the normal pull of gravity with a lesser amount of repulsive matter counteracting the pull of gravity. Areas of light curvature would be areas where there was almost no repulsive matter, and light would be pushed in from the outside as it passed the edge of this area.

I guess in the end it is inconsequential wether there is dark matter or some repulsive matter as both end in the same result, just as any force could be seen as a push or a pull if you put it in the right light. Just some food for thought.

Near the end of the video, did you mean theory in the sense of a tested hypothesis, or did you actually mean hypothesis instead? Because there is a difference...

The theory of evolution and the theory that the earth is round are not hypotheses. They are tested hypotheses: theories.

Also, please do not call a theory JUST a theory in the future because it is suggesting that you are saying that the theory is just a hypothesis.

And if you didn't know that theories aren't hypotheses, then please educate yourself so that you don't appear scientifically illiterate in the future.

I remember reading somewhere that when the universe was still at the particle level of substance after the Big Bang, the balance between matter and anti-matter was almost even, which would've eventually led to all substance in the universe cancelling itself out.
For whatever reason, there was a hair's breadth more matter than anti-matter, so when it all reacted, a tiny bit of matter was left over from all the annihilation, and that's what all the matter and energy in the universe is right now.
If that's truly the case, then could dark energy and matter simply be the reconstituted remnants of that annihilation taking an altered form post-reaction?
It'd account for the imbalance between visible and dark matter and energy, and to my knowledge we're not sure what happens when large amounts of matter and energy annihilate.  The popular understanding is that the annihilation creates energy, but that's just another term for particles, and we don't really know what happens when things settle down, for all we know it could become dark matter and energy, which doesn't possess the photoelectric effect because it's spent.

I think that as many other things in science : the names are misleading.

Like calling inherent propreties of particle "spin" , or of quarks "color".

Calling these strange phenomena dark "energy"/"matter" is misleading for a simple reason :
We don't know if they are energy or matter respectivelly.

A more apt name for "dark matter" would be "dark gravity" , because we see the gravity but nothing else and we have no clue of what causes it , it could be a particle like it could be a phenomena completly removed from our current concepts.

In the same way , calling "dark energy" "energy" is misleading , we know that there's something that causes the expansion of space , we have no clue of what it is.
In the expansion of space there's no "work" involved , to our current knowledge at least. 

Untill i understood these facts these concepts where really hard to wrap my head arround.

So just an advice : be carefull of words , they may only be labels and not mean what they mean.

NOTE :[i'm no expert , so i might be incorrect]
The formula for creating dark matter is 2 parts Plutonic-Quartz, 1 part Cesium, and a full bottle of water

I love me some physics, but I have to admit that dark energy doesn't make a lot of sense.  

We noticed that light shifts in wavelength when we look at distant galaxies, and we take this to mean things are getting farther apart. That is a reasonable conclusion, since light appears to work that way in circumstances we can easily test.  

However, applying that observation has meant that some force must exist which would contain more energy than the rest of the universe combined, but we have no way of testing it and its effects are only clear in this ONE effect.  

Is it entirely unreasonable to suppose that we have the reason for the light shift wrong?  Wouldn't it be more likely that something over great expanses in space causes the wavelength of light to shift than that all of space is filled with magic invisi-energy which only pushes space apart?  Isn't it possible that the universe isn't, in fact, expanding, which cancels the need for dark energy?

I don't know, but when it was put the way it was in this video the assumption of dark energy seemed a little ridiculous to be honest.
